The Tony Hawk series was once one of thé sports titles to look out for every year. reviewText:
Being a fan of the classic TH games I had to check this one out.  THPSHD uses maps from TH1 and 2 (not counting the DLC in this review) as well as the placement of objectives in this undignified remaster. After hearing me say undignified, you may think that I resent this game and think that it should burn in hell for all eternity. IMO, I do not, but it seriously lacks the dignity and respect that Neversoft originally had for the series back in its hayday.

First things first, I bought this game when it was on steam sale for $5, so pricing is not an issue on that end, especially when Robomodo (the developers that took over the TH franchise since TH Ride) sold TH5 for $60, a unhinged pile of ♥♥♥♥. At first i was going to let this one pass as a silly game that would eventually be fixed in the long run, until they pulled the same ♥♥♥♥ on the full retail priced game. But enough of the price on this, lets dive in to the actual game.

the good: For the most part it is a classic TH game with all obectives pretty much in the same place and alot of classic 90s tunes like Superman make a return. Another thing to note is the return of the upgrade with cash system that was used in TH2, which is a nice return to form, also there is an upgraded roster, but lets be honest, if certain skaters are missing, im less likely to care. The last thing i say that is good are the returning levels, like The Warehouse(TH1), The School(TH2),  and The Hanger(TH2). I wish there was more good i could say about it, but that would pretty much be lying at this point.

The Bad: For such a game that could of taken the best ideas from the classic games, Robomodo (and Activision) decided to go the cheap route and make this game as short and barren as they possibly could to maximize profit. This makes me sad because the classics had much replayablility without feeling as repetitive. First thing I am going to hit, is how barren the game is, which is only seven levels long... Seriously... seven? That's it? No Roswell, NM? or Outer space? No Skate street?  Um.. okay. Unfortunately, thats not how shallow this game is. Remember multiplayer back in the ps1 days? Yeah those days are gone. Remember Leaderboards? Yeah, i do too... and its not in here either...How about creating your own skate park? Forget about it! Creating your own skater? ♥♥♥♥ off! Wanna know what we get instead?  Big Head Survival, which is meh okay, and Hawkman...totally sucks. But wait, we havent even gotten to the best part! The physics engine! Oh man...suuuuuucks. Wtf do you think you're doing robomoto? Making a satire of Goat Simulator? I'll admit it's really funny at first, but it gets really tiresome after an hour.

One last thing, which i wont let effect my scoring of this game, but there was one level I left off of the list because i was so disappointed by what was done to it. Marsailles, France used to be my favorite level with how it was a tournament like level between you and the npcs (which you never see skate) that lasts a minute each run and you have to use your best tricks to outbeat your opponent. Well what do you get if you win? Well, a cash prize and a gold medal, which lead to future rewards. Turning my favorite level into a bland objective made me run out of steam in the end and i stopped giving a ♥♥♥♥.

Overall, if you want to check this one out, wait until it is on sale for $5, or better yet, if you own a ps3, buy the classics used for $5 or less on amazon or ebay, and know what true classics are instead of living in a pipe dream with this one.

reviewText:
An old popular skateboarding game got a remake recently, Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater HD. Negatively received in countless sites is it really disappointing? Read on to find out!
Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater HD is a skateboarding game developed by Robomodo. This game takes the best elements of the classic THPS games and gives them a fresh update to create an all new skateboarding experience for the PC.

You probably remember playing this masterpiece with your friends overnight just to hit that perfect combo and feel awesome. Now in stunning visuals, the game tries hard to deliver perfection but falls short at times - stick with me while I explain why.

Gameplay:This game is all about skating around the levels, mastering ramps, nailing those tricks and ultimately stacking up the biggest combo to earn the best score you can. The game kicks off with a variety of old faces to choose from with the worlds biggest skate pros round out the cast including: Nyjah Huston, Chris Cole, Eric Koston, Andrew Reynolds, Rodney Mullen, Lyn-z Adams Hawkins Pastrana, Riley Hawk and of course -Tony Hawk himself. Each skater has over 8 boards, 3 special moves, and an alternate outfit.

Normally you start the career, choose a level and spawn at a fixed place in that level. From there, you  skate and explore around the level to find things you need to complete a task from your list of objectives. Once you complete a certain number of tasks, the next level unlocks ready to be skated out.

Each level has its own unique tasks to complete, once you complete them you earn cash with which you can buy skills, decks or special tricks. Upon completing the whole career mode you'll unlock the second for your character, while another mode unlocks - Projectives mode which requires 100% objective completion across every map (gaps aren't counted). This mode is the same as career mode but offers difficult challenges for those real Pro Skaters.

This game also has the old school free-skate mode where you can explore every unlocked level to find new gaps or hidden areas. Beside free-skate there are also Hawkman and Big Head Survival mode. In Hawkman you have to collect pellets in various ways, they all have different colors and all need a special way to get to clarify this let me explain, red pellets are only collectable during jumps, yellow during grinds, and so on.

In Big Head Survival all you have to do is keep your head growth below 100% or it will explode.. with the typical grow....expand...EXPLODE!. In order to prevent your head from bursting you have to chain combo's and long ones at that otherwise you'll fail and end up without a head not pretty. Both of these modes are great to play because they test your skills and wits. Graffiti mode also makes a return where you gotta nail combos and touch objects, upon completing the combo anything you've touched will change into your characters designated colour, the catch of this mode is to tag more objects than your opponents.

Content:The content of this game is worth for it's price, you get a selection of pro skater levels and it has steam achievements. The new DLC is on it's way.

The length of the game is 10-30 hours, depending on what you do in-game. If you just rush through the career you will finish the game in 10 hours, if you are an achievement enthusiast and want to master everything you'll easily clock 30 hours. Again, it all depends on your personal way of going about with the game.

For me it took 30 hours to get every achievement and game modes (beside hawkman) cleared.

Graphics:The game was rebuilt and polished by Robomodo, using Neversoft’s original level models. All I can say is.. well done Robomodo! We finally have the HD version of the game we've been waiting for (or atleast the die-hard THPS fans). During the exploration of levels you'll just LOVE the sweet and eye-pleasing textures of the game. Everything I remember from the old games is so great to see in HD.

But still there is one thing, just a little thing I didn't like and that is the rag-doll physics in this game. This is just weird, sometimes you just hang around somewhere the other time you have a long neck...you know, graphical glitches.

In the old version when you bailed you'd fall on the ground, grab your board and continue riding, but here when you bail you'll face a white screen and respawn.. I have to say, it's not pretty. Even the blood has been reduced significantly.

Sound:This game has a great soundtrack, it is half classic THPS tracks and half new ones. Still I would love to see more variation of music added and the ability to skip a song like in the old games. Some of the returning tracks are Superman by Goldfinger, Bring the Noise by Public Enemy ft. Anthrax while the newly added tracks are quite good too like Teenage Blood by Apex Manor and many others.


Conclusion:Gameplay: 8/10
+ Addictive if you played the old games
+ Loads of pro-skaters to play with, as well as unlockable bonus skaters
- Sometimes it's hard to complete a level

Content: 6/10
+ Old tony hawk's pro skater levels in HD
+ New game-modes added in singleplayer
+ New upcoming DLC introduces the Revert from Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 (ETA: December 2012)
- No Multiplayer or LAN (just for the PC version)
- No Scoreboards of friends
- Not able to configure or change your controls / graphic settings (needed to be done through a 3rd party launcher or just change the .ini file)

Graphics: 8/10
+ Great HD upgrade since the old games
- Physics are sometimes weird

Sound: 7/10
+ Great music to listen during skateboarding
- More variation of music

Overall Rating: 7/10
A great skateboard game that all Tony Hawks lovers should play at least once to feel how this game really is.

Loads of people disliked this game but I can't see why. Personally I don't really need a multiplayer in this game just old school skating is enough to keep me happy, you could play it with friends in the same room (just passing the controller to each other). Anyway, if you've enjoyed THPS 1 & 2 it's time to grab the remastered version and relive your childhood, or even if you're a newcomer to the series then this is the best time to start your THPS journey.

reviewText:
I was excited to finally play THPS:HD, but immediately regretted my purchase before I was in game.  I was greeted with a 'Powered by Unreal Engine' splash, meaning this is a completely different engine, and then a 'Robomodo' splash, which while I already expected that, was still disappointing to see.  For some background - Robomodo are the people behind the Tony Hawk games that used those plastic motion control boards.

Gameplay:
The balance system is completely terrible, making it impossible for long combos.  In the previous games, every time you would grind or manual in a combo, your balance meter would be slightly reset.  In this game, the balance stays the same until your combo ends, meaning if you jump off a rail and then grind back on, you will most likely bail unless your balance was perfect.

The skater is incredibly slow, and grinding 90% of the time will only make him slower.  Moving just feels slippery and clunky.  Reverts require a DLC, and even then it's just as poorly implemented as the other mechanics.

Levels:
The levels look pretty nice and are spot on with the games they are replicating, though the goals themselves are lazily done.  For example, the competitions are replaced with just collecting 'competition medals' around the map in levels like Marseille.  In the THPS3 DLC maps there's no photo-related goals, and levels like LA have things like the car chase replaced with collecting items around the map.

Conclusion:
In terms of a remake, it just feels like an incomplete skating game with THPS levels and characters.  It doesn't play like a THPS game, it doesn't have mechanics introduced in the games (which are over a decade old), and just altogether isn't very fun to play.

I've tried multiple times to enjoy this game, but I can't.

reviewText:
THPSHD is a very welcome return to the franchise that I adored. But for those of you long-time fans of the series, there is something important to be aware of...

This is strictly a remake using content from THPS 1 and 2 (and 3 in the DLC) Those of you who owned later games in the series will feel very limited in your mobility while playing, as a number of great features have been added over the years that do not make a comeback in this remake...
-Spine and Hip Transfers
-Wallpush and Wallplant
-Walking off your board
If you've used the above features, playing without them is going to make your experience a much less satisfying one without the grace that you may be expecting.

Gameplay aside, the absence of any multiplayer as well as the inibility to create skaters and parks is only further limiting. The best memories I have with the series involve all three of these. Though the ability to skate is there, it feels like so much is missing.

Despite this, I hope this game sells well enough to encourage Robomoto and Activision to produce a more complete remake.

reviewText:
I had played a lot of the Tony Hawk games when I was younger from 1999 until about 2004. I remember when I got the first one for N64 and even began skateboarding in 4th grade because of it. I played:

•	Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater
•	Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater 2
•	Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater 3
•	Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater 4
•	Tony Hawk’s Underground
•	Tony Hawk’s Underground 2

This iteration lacks a lot of the magic from those previous games. I was wondering what it was that made me so bored of this game when it released in 2012, and I revisited it shortly to try to realize why. I discovered the following:

•	No create-a-park, create-a-skater, or really any customizability.
•	The levels feel old, not classic. Also, there are very, very few stages.
•	The unlocking process for each stage is more of a chore because it relies on tasks completed on the previous stage, whereas before you had the option to move to another stage to try to complete those tasks.
•	No way to end your run after completing one specific goal.
•	Awful menu navigation.
•	No multiplayer (not even locally).
•	The “cash” in the game is useless. You use it to purchase tricks, but this is still way more boring than the previous iterations which let you buy stages and boards, etc.
•	A couple of controls are just missing, such as the drop-in button or the leveling button that made it way easier to navigate.

Overall, this port just felt rehashed over lunch, extremely lazy, and money-grabbing. Very poor quality even compared to the very first game in 1999.

There are achievements I guess, but I had tons of fun with this series before achievements were ever a thing.

Steer clear of this one.

reviewText:
See my full review with screenshots and more at http://misstoxia.com/review-tony-hawks-pro-skater-hd/

Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD is definitely aimed at fans of the original Pro Skater series, it features maps, music, skaters and challenges from the early games in a blatant effort to provoke nostalgia from fans like me. The game takes you back to two minute runs with classic career objectives such as getting the secret tape, kick flipping TC’s roof gap and what not. In addition to the Career mode, the game also has a few other game modes such as Big Head Survival, Hawkman and extra Projectives when you finish Career.

Yes, the high school level is back! Yes, the warehouse level is back! And yes you can once again Ollie the Magic Bum 5x. Most of the best levels from Pro Skater and Pro Skater 2 are included as well as three levels from Pro Skater 3 if you purchase the Revert Pack DLC which also adds the revert mechanic which significantly increases your combo potential.

While the game has obviously gotten a huge graphics upgrade, I felt like the physics were a bit… off. Things seemed to feel more realistic in the original games, but in HD it feels like I’m sometimes flying unnaturally through the air. There’s also no animations for stacking/bailing; your character just kinda ragdolls on the spot and spurts out blood.

The PC version unfortunately has a few optimization and other console-porty errors and doesn't contain multiplayer (yet the console version does!). There’s also no skater creator like there was in Pro Skater 2 and 3, but instead, a decent assortment of uncanny-valley-esque professional skaters from both the older games and current real-life professionals.

I personally, really liked HD, I loved the playing the old maps, hearing the old music (the new music was really good too!) and the simplistic game mechanics of the original Pro Skater games before the series let you natas-spin fire hydrants for 10 minutes and walk around off-board whenever you please.

However if you were late to the series you might not find HD as fun as other Tony Hawk’s games, as this is purely a remake of the original Pro Skater games and doesn’t really improve on the old features much, but if you’re looking for a fun childhood nostalgia trip, I recommend you give Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater HD a look.

THPS HD is pretty true to form if you are accustomed to the older style of the THPS series. What does that mean? It means no flatground tricks, sans the manual, no linking together epic scores, and a lot of do-overs for certain goal requirements that are set. I know many are saying these detract, but I honestly find it just as exhilerating and exasperating as I remember. But what I liked about that when I was a kid was that that's how you would actually skate. Pick a spot, set up, and keep at it til you got what you wanted. If you want to progress through the single player, the goals can seem tedious at times, and the physics match the sometimes sluggishness of what the originals had in store for a skater (think wallrides...). That being said, I threw in the towel after THAW, and now that I don't have any next gen console versions, I think this is a fair attempt to recreate some of the charm of the originals, especially with it being decently cheap. Yes, there is no multiplayer, Yes, there is no create-a-skater, yes, there are limited levels, DLC nonwithstanding, however for someone like me who doesn't mind a single skate to just burn an hour away and embrace some nostalgia, this is worth it. reviewText:
This game was developed by Robomodo instead of the original Neversoft, but it is still published by Activision. It is more of a highlight reel put together by fans of the franchise than a 100% port of the original. That being said, it is still very much Tony Hawk Pro Skater and has hours of playability.

The base game has seven levels from THPS 1 & 2 (Warehouse, School II, Hangar, Mall, Venice Beach, Downhill Jam, Marseilles), and the DLC adds three huge maps from THPS 3 (Airport, LA, Canada). An awesome feature they used was that they locked all of the levels, making you play and complete the challenges in order to progress to the next stage. The hidden S-K-A-T-E's are all still in their original places, as well as the VHS's, except they have been changed to DVD's.

Purchasing the DLC also adds the ability to revert during combos on all maps, allowing you to carry them for a longer amount of time. Additional content includes four new skaters: Steve Caballero, Geoff Rowley, James Hetfield and Robert Trujillo of Metallica.

Most of the complaints I see are about wonky physics, but the franchise has always had wonky physics. I booted up my original THPS2 on console and it was pretty damn wonky. But that is what added to the fun and charm of the franchise, at least to me. However, there unfortunately are no multiplayer game modes, and there is also no level editor.

Still highly recommended for skateboarding fans and fans of the franchise!

reviewText:
Done well:

- HD face lift of classic levels
- Aesthetically commendable

Done poorly:

- The engine
- Post-release updates
- Bug moderation
- The soundtrack
- The quality of the game for the price

Read on for a full and thorough review.

A little background:

I think I was proably around 6 or 7 years old when my aunt sent me Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 for the PS1. At the time, I think I may have been obsessed with both Tony Hawk, his franchise of games, and most of all his board company Birdhouse. I can't even remember why I started skateboarding at around the age of 5, but Tony Hawk was definitely my skateboarding idol. To be honest, I can't even remember how much I played THPS3. I played it straight for about 3 years. I don't ever recall playing any other game on my old PS1 slim. I'd beaten career mode with every single playable character, unlocked absolutely every unlockable item, and gained gold in all of the competitions.

The most memorable aspect of the original THPS series were probably the soundtracks. After spending 3 years playing the game as a kid, I had learned pretty much every lyric to every song on the soundtracks. I didn't know who the artist was or what the song was called, but it you chucked the song on play today, I'd be able to sing along to it. Going back and playing the game now (I still have my PS1 copy), I noticed how stable the game's engine is. Despite the poor visuals (it WAS released in 2001), the game never felt chunky or buggy and always ran smoothly. I found this to be pretty consistent with all THPS titles, and this, coupled with Tony Hawk's fame and marketability, is what made the games so successful.

Now:

Fast forward 13 years. I think this was probably my first purcahse on Steam. As I had never really played on PCs before, I opted to use a controller. The controls are identical to the old layout on the PS1 and PS2 controllers - that I was happy about. After playing the games for awhile, the pushing of buttons becomes something as repetitive as changing gears in a car; you can do it quickly and without having to look down at what you're doing.

I really enjoyed seeing a total facelift of the levels in the original games. During the development of the game, the original THPS engine was scrapped and a new one built. While an HD look is less important to me than the feel of the engine, the game does still look pretty nice. It gets let down by the fact that you can see textures render when you spawn. While this doesn't really affect gameplay, it just demonstrates that either this game was rushed, it had very little funding, or that they barely gave two craps when developing it.

The game, as others have mentioned, it ridiculously buggy. I've found myself being thrown in the air and stretched to about four times my length while skating along flatground. I've had countless map breaks. When ollieing onto a rail to perform a grind, it's pretty common that the player will sink through the rail only to then assume the correct position. These bugs are tolerable, but when paying $15 dollars for a game, I don't expect to get something unfinished. Since I have bought the game, no updates or fixes have been implemented to attempt to fix these. It's a little disappointing that the developers pretty much abandoned the game after its first release as this could've had so much potential.

I'd say the game's largest downfall is the 'soundtrack'. As this is a THPS remake, I'd expect it to be filled with the songs from the original games from artists like Alien Antfarm, The Ramones, AFI etc. Sadly, I don't recognise one song from the soundtrack. It seems poorly put together and none of the tracks flow well. Nothing about this remake's soundtrack is recogisable or memorable, and has left a bitter taste in my mouth.

My advice? Sure, this game is fun to play when you're bored or hankering for a nostalgia hit. Is it worth the price? Should you get the DLC? It depnds if you are willing to pay for it, I suppose. I'd suggest you to buy it when and if it's ever on sale. I'd probably pay around 2-5 dollars for this game, not 15. My overall feelings about this game are, well, pretty meh". This HD remake in no way does justice to the greatness of the original THPS series

I really enjoyed seeing a total facelift of the levels in the original games. During the development of the game, the original THPS engine was scrapped and a new one built. While an HD look is less important to me than the feel of the engine, the game does still look pretty nice. It gets let down by the fact that you can see textures render when you spawn. While this doesn't really affect gameplay, it just demonstrates that either this game was rushed, it had very little funding, or that they barely gave two craps when developing it.

The game, as others have mentioned, it ridiculously buggy. I've found myself being thrown in the air and stretched to about four times my length while skating along flatground. I've had countless map breaks. When ollieing onto a rail to perform a grind, it's pretty common that the player will sink through the rail only to then assume the correct position. These bugs are tolerable, but when paying $15 dollars for a game, I don't expect to get something unfinished. Since I have bought the game, no updates or fixes have been implemented to attempt to fix these. It's a little disappointing that the developers pretty much abandoned the game after its first release as this could've had so much potential.

I'd say the game's largest downfall is the 'soundtrack'. As this is a THPS remake, I'd expect it to be filled with the songs from the original games from artists like Alien Antfarm, The Ramones, AFI etc. Sadly, I don't recognise one song from the soundtrack. It seems poorly put together and none of the tracks flow well. Nothing about this remake's soundtrack is recogisable or memorable, and has left a bitter taste in my mouth.

My advice? Sure, this game is fun to play when you're bored or hankering for a nostalgia hit. Is it worth the price? Should you get the DLC? It depnds if you are willing to pay for it, I suppose. I'd suggest you to buy it when and if it's ever on sale. I'd probably pay around 2-5 dollars for this game, not 15. My overall feelings about this game are, well, pretty meh". This HD remake in no way does justice to the greatness of the original THPS series

IF YOU PLAYED ANY OTHER TONY HAWK GAMES, READ THIS:

The levels really feel like the old Pro Skater, its perfect. I still get memories from smashing through the glass at the Warehouse, so I really, really loved that level.

The controls are fun and actually surprisingly good on keyboard. It was really well thought out for convenience. And my hands didn't get tired.

One of the things I disliked, was the lack of characters, or character customization. And also, no multiplayer was a majorly missed opportunity. To be in a clan again would be great. (Also the idea of being in a clan called 'Faze' in Tony Hawk' amused me.

However the characters that were there, looked nice, and the ragdoll was hilarious. It added the goofiness the series had. And when your skater got glitched into the ground like a moleman made me laugh.

I however, did not like the grindbar. Grinding is a major part of the game. The look of the bar should be perfect. But that is  just a small thing.

SUMMERY:

reviewText:
Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD is a good game (and a fine remake).

To address some of the issues that appear in the negative reviews :

- Poor Control. This was an issue that I had when first playing the game with my Logitech Dual Action. The game remained 'playable', however the game had issues when the imputs occured too quickly. Later on I switched to using a Dualshock 3 with ScpServer and have had no issues since (having no problem with clearing all objectives, I refuse to acknowledge 'poor control' as a reason to dismiss this game).

-  Bugs	. Occasionally I have seen some graphical bugs with the textures, as they become blurry for brief moments during gameplay. While I understand that graphical bugs can defeat the purpose of an 'HD remake' for some, please note that this issue rarely occured and had no effect the gameplay itself. Another bug is the result of wonky crash physics that sometimes cause the character to ragdoll or bounce upon wipeout. While some might think this as a bug, it is only experienced once the character has fallen and broken their trick combo. Rest assured that these bugs are only a minor annoyance and will not affect your performance in doing tricks or completing objectives.

- No Multiplayer	. Yeah, I can agree that this sucks. Seeing as how multiplayer was in the ps3/360 port, I don't know why It wasn't implemented in the PC version. I would hope for a multiplayer mod, but it's unlikely that will ever happen.

-  Waah my nostalgia!. Despite the game only containing a few levels from each of the THPS 1-3 games, it remains unchanged from the original games despite the graphical improvements (as an 'HD remake' should have). The music, level design, objectives, skaters and boards are all the same (with the expection of the secret area inside the school not being available. If you can't experience nostalgia here then it seems you might not have had any experience with the original games at all, or your 'nostalgia' has limited you from enjoying this game.

The game also provides plenty of extra game modes that the original games did not, allowing for extended replay value. I had a blast playing this game and could reccomend to anyone looking to play THPS in HD.

reviewText: Not what I was hoping for. The Tony Hawk's series has had a steady decline in quality over the past years and this HD remake was supposed to bring back life to the games. However, it really fails at that. The only thing this game offers is a graphical update of some old, classic Tony Hawk's levels (and some, which suck...seriously? Downhill Jam?) but fails to deliver a good interpretation of the old-school gameplay. Firstly, the physics are a mess. I'm not sure if they tried to blend arcade and realistic gameplay but a lot of the time you find yourself bailing in situations that would be a normal, if somewhat sketchy, landing in previous games. Yes, in real life if you landed like that you would eat a good serving of concrete but not in an old-school Tony Hawk game. We have the EA Skate series for realistic skateboarding frustration, we didn't need that in an arcade skateboarding game. Something else I found awful were the insane difficulty spikes and declines. Of course, this could be contributed to my complete lack of gaming skill but it just feels like they randomly picked some levels and threw them in there in no particular order.\nMy biggest gripe - NO MULTIPLAYER! Not even local multiplayer, let alone online. And this is a big problem, because while the game is mediocre if could have been pretty fun with some people around.\nTony Hawk's Pro Skater HD has 3 good things in it - a pretty good soundtrack, the warehouse level and Chris Cole. Other than that, you're better off getting one of the old games for that nostalgic kick we all need. Only get this if it's stupidly cheap in a sale. The disappointing last gasp of a once proud series that revolutionized funsports games at the turn of the millenium.

The Tony Hawk series of Arcade Sports Sims have been a safe bet from the get-go as far as fluid and fun gameplay, inventive level design, great soundtracks and charming humour are concerned. Some of these elements can be found in this HD remake of a small selection of levels and songs from Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 1 and 2 brought back from the dead with the voodoo of the Unreal Engine which as usual does an admirable job even after so many years. The classics don't lose their magic and you will keep finding new lines and combos even after years (and I should know, I've been playing the series since 1999) however the selection of levels and songs is rather small and the levels themselves aren't big either, because they were designed with the limitations of late nineties consoles. There is not much to do here,a tiny assortment of gameplay modes that each eschew any sort of invitation to play them for more than a few rounds. A tiny amount of purely cosmetic unlockables, play it through once, never pick it up again. There's also no multiplayer on PC.

This anorexic approach to game design is further mangled by a failed revamping of the gameplay. The new physics engine lacks the tight and fluid control that the series is known for. There are no ways to change key bindings in-game, the process to change the .ini files is lengthy and tedious for anyone not playing with the xbox controller and even then the controls just seem off or wobbly for lack of a more technical term. Graphical settings are handled in the same shoddy manner. ini or die.

THPS HD comes off as the final lazy attempt to cash in on the last breath of a dead series. Namesake Tony Hawk always seemed very sincere about the series he helped create and connected it deeply in skate culture, but here they just dropped the ball so hard it tunneled miles past where the catastrophic Tony Hawk's Shred and Ride finally came to rest covered in money glued on with the tears of children who got them as christmas gifts.

There's no real market for this game. Old fans will be disappointed, newcomers will be turn off their computer in frustration. If you want to play the series again or the first time on PC, there are so many better options. Tony Hawk's Underground 1 and 2 run well on modern systems because of a dedicated modding community, THPS 2 to 4 were also released on PC. Even buying the first two games on playstation for the estimated 2 bucks they will cost you and firing up an emulator will get you a better experience overall and better introduction to a great series of times past, filled with hours upon hours of highly addictive fun.

Some of these elements can be found in this HD remake of a small selection of levels and songs from Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 1 and 2 brought back from the dead with the voodoo of the Unreal Engine which as usual does an admirable job even after so many years. The classics don't lose their magic and you will keep finding new lines and combos even after years (and I should know, I've been playing the series since 1999) however the selection of levels and songs is rather small and the levels themselves aren't big either, because they were designed with the limitations of late nineties consoles. There is not much to do here,a tiny assortment of gameplay modes that each eschew any sort of invitation to play them for more than a few rounds. A tiny amount of purely cosmetic unlockables, play it through once, never pick it up again. There's also no multiplayer on PC.

This anorexic approach to game design is further mangled by a failed revamping of the gameplay. The new physics engine lacks the tight and fluid control that the series is known for. There are no ways to change key bindings in-game, the process to change the .ini files is lengthy and tedious for anyone not playing with the xbox controller and even then the controls just seem off or wobbly for lack of a more technical term. Graphical settings are handled in the same shoddy manner. ini or die.

THPS HD comes off as the final lazy attempt to cash in on the last breath of a dead series. Namesake Tony Hawk always seemed very sincere about the series he helped create and connected it deeply in skate culture, but here they just dropped the ball so hard it tunneled miles past where the catastrophic Tony Hawk's Shred and Ride finally came to rest covered in money glued on with the tears of children who got them as christmas gifts.

There's no real market for this game. Old fans will be disappointed, newcomers will be turn off their computer in frustration. If you want to play the series again or the first time on PC, there are so many better options. Tony Hawk's Underground 1 and 2 run well on modern systems because of a dedicated modding community, THPS 2 to 4 were also released on PC. Even buying the first two games on playstation for the estimated 2 bucks they will cost you and firing up an emulator will get you a better experience overall and better introduction to a great series of times past, filled with hours upon hours of highly addictive fun.

This game is alright, it feels like a mashup of THPS 1-3 with some new skaters. The game itself is visually appealing, but I am dissapointed that the only option in the graphics menu is the ability to alter the resolution, this is a little shabby for a modern PC port. The selection of levels is OK, although personally I feel they could have added a few more to the mix, such as downtown minneapolis from THPS1, Skate street from THPS2. My only problem with the levels is that some of them haven't been adapted to the new game engine, meaning that certain gaps and goals are now more difficult to achieve than in the original games, one of the main examples of this is the venice beach level in which certain gaps and goals have had their difficulty unneccessarily increased, this down to the fact that your skater moves slower than in the classic games. The new engine is nice and it feels like they tried to emulate the THPS3 engine but with more realistic movement, however the game will sometimes throw you off your board even if you don't bail, this can be annoying when trying to get a high score. I'm not too bothered about the lack of multiplayer but local multiplayer/splitscreen would have been an asset here. I'm also dissapointed that you can't dismount your board in order to look around a level in order to find certain goals like in the THUG games. In conclusion it has potential but it feels rushed, it feels like they spent more time porting the levels and making all the movements seem hyper realistic that they forgot to see whether or not their game actually worked properly.

tl;dr, buy this if its on sale like I did, otherwise stick to the older games as THUG, THUG-2 and THAW all feature updated versions of the classic levels

The disappointing last gasp of a once proud series that revolutionized funsports games at the turn of the millenium.

The Tony Hawk series of Arcade Sports Sims have been a safe bet from the get-go as far as fluid and fun gameplay, inventive level design, great soundtracks and charming humour are concerned. Some of these elements can be found in this HD remake of a small selection of levels and songs from Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 1 and 2 brought back from the dead with the voodoo of the Unreal Engine which as usual does an admirable job even after so many years. The classics don't lose their magic and you will keep finding new lines and combos even after years (and I should know, I've been playing the series since 1999) however the selection of levels and songs is rather small and the levels themselves aren't big either, because they were designed with the limitations of late nineties consoles. There is not much to do here,a tiny assortment of gameplay modes that each eschew any sort of invitation to play them for more than a few rounds. A tiny amount of purely cosmetic unlockables, play it through once, never pick it up again. There's also no multiplayer on PC.

This anorexic approach to game design is further mangled by a failed revamping of the gameplay. The new physics engine lacks the tight and fluid control that the series is known for. There are no ways to change key bindings in-game, the process to change the .ini files is lengthy and tedious for anyone not playing with the xbox controller and even then the controls just seem off or wobbly for lack of a more technical term. Graphical settings are handled in the same shoddy manner. ini or die.

THPS HD comes off as the final lazy attempt to cash in on the last breath of a dead series. Namesake Tony Hawk always seemed very sincere about the series he helped create and connected it deeply in skate culture, but here they just dropped the ball so hard it tunneled miles past where the catastrophic Tony Hawk's Shred and Ride finally came to rest covered in money glued on with the tears of children who got them as christmas gifts.

There's no real market for this game. Old fans will be disappointed, newcomers will be turn off their computer in frustration. If you want to play the series again or the first time on PC, there are so many better options. Tony Hawk's Underground 1 and 2 run well on modern systems because of a dedicated modding community, THPS 2 to 4 were also released on PC. Even buying the first two games on playstation for the estimated 2 bucks they will cost you and firing up an emulator will get you a better experience overall and better introduction to a great series of times past, filled with hours upon hours of highly addictive fun.

Before you judge my review on my hilariously low play time, hear me out- I played this game on Xbox 360 for quite some time; then I moved to PC (I actually pirated it because of how bad I heard it was), and then here we are now. So I've certainly had my run through this game, many times. That being said, let me get into it.

So I've been a THPS fan ever since I was a kid. As many people did, I started out on THPS 2 and went forwards (yes I did play THPS 1, but the disc got scratched to hell so I never got to finish it...). I absolutely adored skating; so much that I took a passion for it irl. Although I was a skater in real life, I always loved skating in video games better because I can't do tricks worth s hit. Regardless, I think like a skater and I know how a skating game should work.

THPS HD was such a GREAT idea that was pitched in 2012, but sadly, it just didn't deliver. The game often crashed for me when I played the pirated version, but I didn't experience any crashes on the legal version. The only two things that I absolutely hate about this game are the 1. 720p auto downsample and 2. The screen tearing is VERY BAD. Regarding the downsample- the game WILL run in 1920x1080 resolution, but the textures can only be seen at 1240x720, which makes textures and objects look pretty horrid. Did I also mention that the rendering for lots of objects and models take 5 more seconds than they should? Because they do. And it pisses me off sometimes. Regarding the screen tearing- THPS HD is VERY bad with this. Leaning to the left or to the right when going moderately fast is just an eyeful of what looks like my screen ripping itself in half. It's just so bad to look at sometimes, and it almost makes me nautious looking at it. There's no Vsync option neither, so that's no fun.

Regarding the physics of the HD remake- they're mediocre and need fine tuning. The grind collision between your character and the rail is absolutely horrible; sometimes, it's like you're 10 feet away from the rail, but yet you'll float to the rail if you press the grind key. While this can help in some situations, it's still pretty annoying when you're trying to make a REALISTIC game. I might also add that the biggest problem with the physics is the bailing. Sometimes you will completely 100% land a trick, but completely bail out instead. Same thing can happen with grinding rails and/or awkwardly hitting a vert ramp.

While the arcade gameplay was an ABSOLUTE blast from the past, it was basically the only thing that gave me serious nostalgia other than the levels and OST.

I forgot to mention that the OST is the same exact one from THPS 1, which is a BIG plus. I think that's one of my most favorite parts of the game- jamming out to old tunes from one of the greatest games of all time.

Other than the OST and levels, this game doesn't have much going for it. It's got the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ physics engine from THPS 5, and we all know how cancerous THPS 5 was. The skater selection is very scearce and the board shop is agrugably the worst in the entire franchise. There is no character customization, no level creater, nothing. It's just strictly  Arcade, Free Skate, and several other modes that are unlocked. If this game had more to it and didn't charge $4.99 for a few levels that SHOULD have been added in as FREE DLC, I think I would give it the benefit of the doubt and give it a good-ish review, but this game just has far too many issues and should be repolished before ever coming into the Steam marketplace. I've seen Early Access games perform and function better than THPS HD.

I bought this game on sale for $4.99, which is relatively cheap and I don't really feel cheated out of my money, so I'm not going to refund. I'm certainly happy with this game just because of all the nostalgia it brings back and it being the only REAL 3D skateboarding game on PC (OlliOlli doesn't count because it's 2D). Bottom line; buy this game when it's on sale. I would regret paying $19.99 for this game on any retail day.

This game gets a lot of negative reviews, but since I haven’t played any of the old THPS or any TH games, I still enjoy it.

When you start the game, you can select from several different skaters who weren’t in the older games like Tony Hawk’s son Riley Hawk. Each character has their own special ability, for instance Rodney Mullen is great at doing manuals in the game while other characters may not be as good. The levels to the game are taken from THPS and it’s sequel THPS2, ranging from a hangar to a mall. The music can get quiet annoying and repetitive throughout the levels.

When you are playing through the objective mode, the levels can seem monotonous since all your doing is tricks and collecting things. On some stages its really fun to do the objectives but on others, not so much. If you get tired of doing the same old objectives, you can take a break in Free Skate mode. I actually find that mode to be somewhat relaxing. There are a few other modes like one where you have to follow a certain path doing a certain kind of trick.

There is one DLC pack that adds some more mechanics, stages, and characters from THPS3.

Overall, I like the game. It does have its issues like the repetitiveness, but it has plenty of redeeming qualities like fun gameplay.

I rate this game a 8/10
